comments.commentBody:
Excellent comment. As a strong supporter of Bernie Sanders, I shall be doing my unpleasant civic duty of casting my vote for Hillary Clinton in November.

At the same time, I will cast my down ballot votes for Democrats and do my best to support progressive policies in 2017 and beyond.

The English national team has not won anything with Rooney in the lineup. Since 2010, it has become almost embarrassing to watch England.

Time for Rooney to go somewhere else... Maybe in the MLS?

On the team: For once with Man U, it was beautiful movement soccer (at least for the half that counted).

I've only been watching them since the last 2 years of Ferguson, but they looked better (much better) in the 1st half, than I've ever seen them (so many of the victories under Ferguson that I saw, came despite their being outplayed almost the entire game, but believing in themselves enough to come out ahead - along of course with some remarkable passes and game management by the often by then sub Giggs).

On Rooney: I obviously missed his great years. For someone who can't dribble, can't create his own shot, used to have (that I saw) composure to score when receiving the ball in scoring position, and able to make some brilliant passés, he's scored a lot of goals! To me, even when he was scoring goals, an extremely one dimensional player. Now he's kind of like the Charles Barkley of the EPL - completely distorting the flow of the game for his own ponderous plans, which often go nowhere. No fun to watch. A dark cloud on the flow of the game. Better moved to other pastures if he wants to keep playing.
Rashford was a major find...by Louis Van Gaal, who has prized and played young players throughout his career, the diametric oposite of Mourinho.

Rooney will have his days, but he's going to be the super sub for the foreseeable future. Rashford has been a major find, while Zlatan is an established superstar. Jose would be crazy to start Rooney up front with those guys available. That said, Rooney will surely get his time in, but mostly as a midfielder. Never say never, just think of how negative Jose has been in the past about Mata and look at how he's been proven wrong.

The real problem in Deflategate is that the standard for the league was that Brady 'probably had general knowledge'....and that the result would be loss of draft picks, 4 game suspension, 1m fine. That, on its face, is ridiculous.

You can leave exponent and its testing out of it.

It is some comfort that the other ALEast owners are having it all crammed back down their throats. I doubt that Goodell is all that concerned.

The case will never be closed, although we are all sick of it.

At the time, I found it fascinating to see legal, and regular, minds at work, how language can be used to clarify or obscure 'facts', how critical thinking can be applied, how nothing is ever simple or obvious.

Now, think how trials work, when much more serious matters are at issue.

If the officials on the field never noticed it, then how could it possibly matter in the bigger picture? The officials are there to spot and punish malfeasance. The officials are the only people who touch the ball on every play. If they didn't notice  significantly under-inflated balls, then for all practical purposes the balls were fine. Case closed.
True. But, so what.

My Debate Nightmare? One-sided coverage about Donald Trump.This article has 30 references to Donald Trump, and 23 references to Hillary Clinton.

Can we please have some equal coverage for both HRH Hillary Clinton and Mr. Trump. A debate is supposed to be two-sided, but I can just see the articles from the NYTimes the next day - My debate nightmare - all negative articles about Mr. Trump and all glowing reviews about Hillary Clinton.

I can't resist:

I rabbi, a monk, a spiritualist, and a swami walk into a bar...

Amen to all Carnicelli except for "representative of Islam" because what is unequivocally deemed "Islam" is not. Qur'an is. It admonishes on multiple occasions to not divide the the religion into sects. Therefore, there aren't as many Moslems on earth as the census bureau would have us believe. Anyone who puts a / past Moslem be it Sunni, Shiite, Sufi etc with further slash marks for Sunni/Wahhabi, Sunni/Salefi, bla bla is in violation of the Qur'an, which indeed puts a bigger emphasis on anti-sectarianism  than pork, alcohol, adultery combined! There are practical considerations and eventual forgiveness mentioned for all three, but none for dividing religion into sects "after knowledge has reached them", be it Moslem, Jew,  or Christian. That's why the Sunni/Shiite rivalry has fomented so much nonsense and evil while driven by clergy on the payroll.

And the bartender says, "What is this--a joke?'

How can all these non-materialists afford Tribeca?

One of the first sects that I encountered as a young spiritual seeker was Sufism - and although I was never tempted to join, I was nonetheless favorably impressed.

If all Islam were like Sufism, there would be no hostility towards Islam in the west. Unfortunately, Sufism is not especially representative of Islam.

As regards the comments of Mr. Morrow later in this piece, I could not disagree more. You can profitably pick and choose parts of any religion on earth - and I encourage everyone to do so.

If God exists, and has inspired spiritual traditions across the planet, each intended for use in a specific time and place, and best understood by careful exploration of the culture of that time and place - as He surely has if He can be said to authentically exist - then sectarian doctrine is ultimately little more than the husk of an ancient harvest, no longer wholly fit for consumption by modern men.

I would submit that the task for modern men and women of faith and spirit must be to go beyond the ancient forms, to remove the ancient blinders, and instead identify those living principles that animate every tradition and emphasize our essential, shared humanity - old and new, eastern and western. For if God authentically exists, then He, She, or It has inspired all of them. And rumor has it that He, She, or It continues to inspire authentic seekers, even to this day.

Namaste.

It's the "usual" overinflation of Mrs. Clinton from the NYTimes. First there was nary a mention of Mr. Sanders from day 1 of the Democratic campaign. Then there were the daily barrages of everything negative about Donald Trump. And of course, Mrs. Clinton was the "Princess in Waiting", with anything written about her being totally glowing.  I'm surprised the cartoonist didn't shrink Mr. Trump of make Mrs. Clinton even taller!

254. 13 died afterwards. Why didn't Congress call Reagan and a grill him for these unnecessary deaths?

Because Reagan was a Republican, and the Teflon Republican at that.

Truth be told, Iraq War 2 began during the Clinton administration, when Saddam Hussein's regime was softened up by draconian economic sanctions that left 500,000 children dead ("The price is worth it," said Sec'y State Albright) and by constant bombings that destroyed much of the nation's infrastructure. Bush merely picked up from where Clinton left off, just as the Obama administration has meant a continuation of Bush's aggressive militarism. Hillary Clinton? More of the same...30 years of war in the Middle East. And our pundits wonder why Americans are disaffected...
And we know that Donald is a really tough guy because he growls and snarls like Adolph and he swears a lot.

"there’s one thing I know for sure: George W. Bush kept us safe.”....except for the 3000 Americans killed on Sept 11 2011, the 6.800 American servicemen killed in Iraq and Afghanistan and the 1,800 Americans killed by Hurricane Katrina...and the 2008 economic collapse.

I never equated 'safe' with death and catastrophe, but you know those Bushes...they've always been challenged by the English language.

The point is we all know how wonderfully safe Republican nincompoops will keeps us.

Republicans think they're strong on defense because they hate diplomacy and prefer to brag, boast, invade first and ask questions later.

Republicans also think they're good at managing the economy because the economy and the budget collapses every time they cut recklessly cut taxes.

Many Republicans also think Saddam Hussein was connected to Sept, 11, but it turns out it was just a right-wing hallucination.

Many Republicans still think President Obama is a Kenyan Muslim, but it turned out to be just a figment of their white supremacy.

Many Republicans believe Up Is Down and Down Is Up because they have been taught to be detached from reality.

Donald Trump and Bush-Cheney and their daddies kept themselves safe in the USA while 58,000 fellow American soldiers died in Vietnam.

Ronald Reagan's command let 241 Americans died in Beirut, the deadliest single terrorist attack on American citizens in general prior to the September 11 attacks.

Republicans are pretty good at keeping nothing safe.

Congrats. In case this will help with your next bar bet, Ase's a she and it's Norwegian.

I'm feeling like I'll be feeling better tomorrow. Elaine feels lousy now.
Anyone who loved Howard Pyle's books knows about the trusty YEW bow....

.
.
CROSSWORDESE

Martin, I read a lot about "crosswordese". In this grid, OSE might be condemned as "crosswordese" by Rex or Amy. Constructor Jeff may have called OSE a "gluey bit".

You are by now familiar with my belief that many such entries are useful to someone. Chemists may be more likely to speak of sucrOSE or glucOSE, but it's useful to know OSE as a denotation of a sugar. ASE denotes an enzyme, or a guy who dies in some Danish work.

"Useful" is my focus here.

At the Downriver Golf Club, the clubhouse is used one night a week for a Trivia competition, open to nonmembers. First prize is SCRIP worth $20 against a bar/restaurant bill there. Second and third prizes are lesser SCRIP.

One night, a question was put to the competitors: Name the tree that fits a certain description. In the 3-part description, one element was the traditional use of the tree's wood to make longbows. Therefore, I wrote YEW on the answer sheet without consulting my teammates. Why? Because YEW appears in crosswords as an archer's wood. Is YEW CROSSWORDESE? Not to me. Our bill was over $100 with tip. Another team member had also offered to pay, in honor of our teammate who was moving back to SF the next morning, so our pre-arrangement was that I would pay $90 and my teammate could pay the rest.

We won by one point. That point was for YEW. I saved 22% off my $90 contribution after the team voted that I should reap the benefit of the SCRIP. If a grid word saves me $20, it's a real word.

I thought there was an expression about "size".

It went something like "It's not the size that counts, it's how you use it. Of course the original older expression was: "it's not the size of the dog in the fight, but the size of the fight in the dog".

Real estate is hardly 'cookie cutter' and is a dynamic and creative field. That said, Donald Trump is looked at as a third string player in the commercial real estate industry, known more for his bankruptcies and defaults than for his innovations and successes.

Trump's business record ranges from dismal to middling, and does not speak well of his qualifications for president.

I'm hardly a Hillary Clinton fan, but I recognize that she's the far better choice for the presidency this year. That judgment is bolstered by Trump's business record.

Keep up the good work, hen3ry.

Introverts Unite ! (in total solitude)

Eric  Trump told Fox yesterday that his "dad was a basically self made man" and even the Lying Faux Station had to say that "Trump started with a million dollar loan" when we know that Trump got $14 Million in starter money and bail outs from His father, some even made illegally by a lawyer buying chips at his casino in NJ and Never cashing them in.  Further, Trump was near bankruptcy again Just Before he stiffed thousands of small companies and then was given the Apprentice stupid show. Now Trump has ties with Putin in Russia where Trump's Advisor told Putin that Trump would Stop the Embargo w/Russia over Crimea and now US Agents are investigating this and also the Hacking of State Election Computers and the Democratic Party computers and now Gen Powell's and a White House Staffer ; with a Iranian government official, his son and a Business in Asia where Trump is money laundering Millions through this so called "company" and US is investigating this; Trump's using FEC laws to Charge the Federal Government almost $4 Million dollars for the privilege of the Secret Service flying with his plane in order to protect him, and the Continual Lies about why he Will NOT release his taxes when we ALL know the reasons why: He is NOT a Billionaire, He is NOT Paying One Cent in Taxes for over 30 years, He is Investing with Foreign Governments who are hostile to America like Russia, China, Turkey and too many others to name, He NEVER Donates to Charity Ever Ever Ever and he is a Jerl.
Or, she could say that we don't know if Trump paid any taxes at all since the last time he filed in 1980, when it revealed that he paid 0 in the late 70's.
@Jacky: She can say that she got the info from a former IRS employee.  Or from one of his former accountants. Or from one of his former tax attorneys. Or from one of his former mistresses.

Two suggestions for HRC: One of the few things that appall both progressives and conservatives is an ungrateful child. For the past year (perhaps more) The Donald has continually played up the notion that he's a self-made success, a man who has single-handedly built his company into a billion-dollar enterprise. Even were we to overlook the contributions of his staff and other corporate officers, the fact of the matter is that it was Mr. Trump's father who built that company from the ground up and who passed it along as an inheritance to his Donald and his siblings. Has anyone ever heard him even mention his old man? How many of us, whatever our political convictions, would take credit for the accomplishments of our parents?
Suggestion# 2: Lie. Kind of. If things get really tight Monday, why not do what The Donald himself does virtually every time he opens his mouth? If it's okay for Mr. Trump to have libeled the incumbent President of the United States with the falsehood that he was born abroad even after he presented his U.S. birth certificate, why not simply announce that your opponent has paid absolutely no taxes for a period of, say, ten years? More than likely, this allegation would prove accurate. In any case, the only way it could be shown to be false is via the submission of Mr. Trump's tax returns. Let's get real: there's only one reason why The Donald hasn't released them by now. Either he accepts Hillary's allegation or he submits the t/r's.
Np it doesn't.  Clinton is the candidate who knows what she's doing
The NYTimes Clinton endorsement reflects Hobson's choice.

.
I broke my personal Sunday speed record by a few seconds, but that means less if the puzzle was very easy!! For some reason, my fastest Sundays have been Patrick Berry puzzles, Jeff Chen puzzles, or puzzles with 2 constructors. So I think my previous Sunday was a puzzle by Judge Vic and someone else. Pair Jeff Chen with another constructor, and it's a recipe for speed for me.

That's not to say there were no stumbling blocks. MISSENd or MISSENT??? INTIME or oNTIME?? I usually made the wrong choice. I did not have any reason to think I was going fast.

But solve times this week were awry in my experience. Fastest was Monday, then Tuesday, as expected. Wednesday was hard for a Wednesday (slower than my average, whereas Mon and Tue were right around my averages for those days, so the gap between Tuesday's solve time and Wednesday's was larger than I expect). After Wednesday things got weird. I solved Friday's less than a minute slower than Wednesday's. But Thursday was slower than Friday (by the same margin as I had between Tuesday and Wednesday).

I usually expect Thursdays to require a range of time for the solve; this past Thursday solve time was slower than midrange. Friday's solve time would have been near the low end of Thursday range. Then Sunday solved less than a minute slower than Thursday; Saturday took me half a minute more than Sunday. So my order from fastest to slowest was M, T, W (by more than usual), F, Th, Sun, Sat. Not a typical crossword week for me.

Because sometimes it is the tone of the article [as in the 2003 Clinton article or the recent article describing her as 'politician's-wife-turned-politician-herself'] rather than the information which is updated.  No new information is added, only the tone is revised.

AP updates its stories many times daily, has for many decades. As a wire desk vet, I know they always signal to editors how each new "writethru" is different and why. As a transparency, media outlets should do it for readers too. It's hardly a big deal.

The digital age is fast paced.

Why not just note that the article has been updated to reflect additional information?
Thank you. And you're very cute.
I assume because the Times feels that possible protest votes would undercut a Clinton victory.  She HAS to win big to emphasize we're all Americans together at this dangerous time in world history
The lesser of two evils is still evil.  Why did NYT feel the need to endorse ANYone?

In this email of quick solutions,of instantaneous gratification,of lack of clear & inclusive views,that NYT has endorsed a candidate reflecting American values of our Constitution. "....In order to form a more perfect Union..." I hope America does not forget this value. It is strange that some Americans think by electing a privileged,narcissistic,non-Christian,that will make us great. By any political parties standards, a Trump Presidency is un-American. A twisted,un-ethical candidate of selfishness. Is he the culmination of the "Me Generation"? of the 1980's?
And you prefer Trump?

Hear! Hear!

Thank you - Hillary Clinton will make a fantastic president and I can't wait to vote for her on November 8th.

History awaits, tell everyone you know to get out and vote!
FINALLY!!!  It's about time. Hopefully this endorsement will overcome the damage your prior equivalency commentary had done.
So aside from complaining, what are you doing to improve the situation in your community, your city? Do you vote in local and state elections or only when it "matters"?
